prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For not wanting to get my wife’s DOB tattooed on me along with our daughters and my parents?
The idea behind the tattoo is that it would show my lineage.  My Parents > Me> My Daughter in Roman numerals stacked oldest to youngest, bottom to top.  

For some reason my wife thought that her DOB would be included in this tattoo and was shocked and upset her DOB was not included.  To make the situation worse, my mother (who has no tattoos) sided with my wife under the idea that our daughter was a product of both my wife and I.    I don’t know if they are confusing the idea with family tree despite me saying I was using it to show my lineage or direct descendants.

AITA for not wanting my wife’s dob on my body / changing the design of the tattoo. Cuse I’m having serious second thoughts about getting it done.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The author might have made a mistake by not discussing this more thoroughly with his wife before finalizing the design. The mother's support for the wife adds pressure, which could escalate the situation. 

On the other hand, the author had the right to design the tattoo as he saw fit. However, since it's a family-related tattoo involving their child, the wife's feelings are valid. The wife's shock and upset reaction suggest that her expectations were important to her, and the author didn't account for that.

So, while the author isn't necessarily in the wrong for not including the wife's DOB, the way the situation was handled—without considering the wife's feelings and not clarifying the design's intent—might make him partially at fault.
